title: Raffaella Carrà
subtitle: An overview on Raffaella Carrà's life and work
curator: Miriam Longhitano, Laura Cigno, Anna Avona
description: This project will be about one of the best Italian singer songwriters from Bologna: Raffaella Carrà.  She was of the best Italian singer-songwriters. As a substantial part of Italian culture, we will analyze her life and works.

dynamic_elements.text:
Raffaella Carrà was an iconic Italian singer, actress, television personality, and dancer, whose charismatic performances and influential career spanned over five decades. Born on June 18, 1943, in Bologna, Italy, as Raffaella Maria Roberta Pelloni, she became one of the most beloved and influential figures in Italian entertainment history. Carrà's versatile talents, combined with her infectious energy and groundbreaking contributions to music and television, made her an international superstar. Carrà began her career in the 1960s as a dancer and chorus girl in various Italian television programs. Her talent and captivating presence quickly caught the attention of audiences, leading to her breakthrough as a singer with the release of her debut single, "Fortissimo," in 1965. The song achieved significant success and marked the beginning of a fruitful music career. In the 1970s, Carrà's popularity soared, both in Italy and internationally. She released numerous hit singles, including "Tanti Auguri," "A far l'amore comincia tu," and "Fiesta," which became anthems of the era and established her as a symbol of female empowerment and liberation. Carrà's unique blend of disco, pop, and dance music, accompanied by her vibrant choreography and glamorous style, made her an idol for millions of fans. Alongside her music career, Carrà ventured into acting, starring in a variety of films and television shows. She showcased her acting prowess in movies such as "Ma che musica maestro" (1971) and "Pronto... c'è una certa Giuliana per te" (1971). Carrà also hosted her own television programs, such as "Canzonissima" and "Fantastico," where she showcased her talent for hosting, dancing, and entertaining audiences with her infectious charm. In the 1980s, Carrà's influence expanded beyond Italy. She gained popularity across Europe, particularly in Spain and Latin America, where she hosted her own Spanish-language television shows and achieved immense success with hits like "En el amor todo es empezar" and "Lucas" . Beyond her music and television career, Carrà was also known for her philanthropic work and advocacy. She supported various charitable causes, including HIV/AIDS research and the rights of women and the LGBTQ+ community. Her humanitarian efforts further endeared her to her fans and solidified her legacy as a compassionate and influential figure. On July 5, 2021, Raffaella Carrà passed away at the age of 78 in Rome, Italy, leaving behind a remarkable legacy.
